speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: Have you ever been to an all-you-can-eat buffet, Sam? You know – a meal in a restaurant where you can eat as much food as you like.

speaker: Sam
text: Yes, I went to an Indian buffet once. I didn’t eat all day before the meal, but I only managed to finish three or four plates…well, maybe five!

speaker: eyes were bigger than your belly
text: It sounds like your eyes were bigger than your belly, or stomach –  a phrase describing someone who has taken more food than they can eat. In this programme we’ll be discussing buffets – a feast of many different food dishes where diners are allowed to eat as much as they want – or as much as their stomachs will allow. And, of course, we’ll be learning some new vocabulary as well.

speaker: Sam
text: The popularity of buffets is booming, especially in Middle Eastern and Asian countries where the variety of foods means there’s something for everyone. But feasts are big and boastful - usually too much is cooked, and buffets have been criticised for waste.

speaker: Neil
text: We’ll hear more soon, but first I have a question for you, Sam. The word ‘buffet’ originated from the French name for the table on which food was served, but buffets themselves don’t come from France. So in which country did buffets begin?

speaker: Neil
text: a)     The United States of America

speaker: Neil
text: b)    Sweden

speaker: Neil
text: c)     China

speaker: Neil
text: Sam

speaker: Neil
text: Well, the US is famous for supersizing food so I’ll guess a) America.

OK, Sam. We’ll find out the answer later in the programme. John Wood, owner of cooking company Kitchen Cut, knows a lot about buffets – he used to run a one thousand seat breakfast buffet at the five-star Jumeirah Beach Hotel in Dubai. Here John shares his observations on human buffet behaviour with BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain.

speaker: pile get your money's worth.
text: There are different people that treat buffets in different ways. Some people think this is a great opportunity to try little bits and lots of everything, and we come back as many times as I like. And other people just - whether they don't like getting up and down, which is understandable from their table - just want to pile it high, and people they want to getvalue for money. So, if you're paying $100, $200 a head for a buffet, you're gonna pile it up high and take the most expensive things you can you know, and get your money's worth.

speaker: get their money’s worthpile uppile something up,pile
text: John says buffet diners want to get their money’s worth – get good value for the money they spend, so they often pile up food on their plate. If you pile something up, you gather a large amount of it into one place to build what’s called a pile.

speaker: Neil
text: But buffets are not just about eating until you explode - they’re also an opportunity to show off to your friends. Weddings are big in India, and usually include a buffet. The richer the people getting married, the bigger the buffet, sometimes inviting as many as five thousand guests. If each guest eats around six dishes, we’re taking about a seriously big buffet!

speaker: caterer
text: Sandeep Sreedharan is a wedding caterer from Goa in South India – he owns a company which provides the food and drink for special social occasions. Here he talks with Ruth Alexander, presenter of BBC World Service, The Food Programme, about organising an Indian wedding buffet:

speaker: vicious circle
text: It's a very vicious circle, I think, right? Everybody wants to overwhelm everybody around you.

speaker: knock their socks off.
text: OK. That's the aim. They are out to impress - they want to ‘wow’ the guests - knock their socks off.

speaker: caterer?
text: Knock their socks off. They should just go back saying,  ‘I couldn't eat even half of it!’, you know. Some people just come for eating. They don't even worry about who's wedding is it… They know that… ‘Who's the caterer? Ah, these guys are catering. Oh my God, this is gonna be great.

speaker: knock their socks off
text: Wedding buffets are designed to amaze and overwhelm the guests with their huge displays of food. They need to ‘wow’ the guests, or knock their socks off – an idiom meaning to amaze and impress someone.

speaker: vicious circle
text: The problem is that no matter how extravagant and expensive one buffet is, the next one has to be even more impressive, something Sandeep calls a vicious circle – a difficult situation which has the effect of creating new problems which then make the original situation even worse.

speaker: Sam
text: It seems the secret to enjoying a buffet is trying a little bit of everything, without stuffing yourself until you can’t move – although in the past, I think, that was exactly the idea.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, it’s time to reveal the answer to my question - where did the buffets originally come from?

speaker: Sam
text: I guessed it was from the United States. Was I right?

speaker: Neil
text: That was… the wrong answer, I’m afraid, Sam. In fact buffets are thought to have come from Sweden in the Middle Ages.

speaker: eyes bigger than your belly,
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned, starting with the expression, eyes bigger than your belly, or eyes bigger than your stomach,used when someone has taken more food than they can eat.

speaker: pile up pile
text: If you pile up your plate,you gather a large quantity of food together into a pile.

speaker: get your money’s worth
text: The phrase to get your money’s worth means to get good value for the money you have spent .

speaker: vicious circle
text: A vicious circle is a problematic situation, having the effect of creating new problems which then make the first situation even worse.

speaker: knock your socks off
text: The idiom to knock your socks off means to wow, amaze or impress someone.

speaker: caterer
text: And finally, a caterer is a person or company which provides food and drink for special social occasions. Once again, our six minutes are up. Bye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye!
